2:803–17, Viðar Hreinsson considers this saga to be the oldest in Sturlunga saga. He provides a careful analysis of the authorial strategies that set Sturla off from his antagonists and allow him to emerge gradually as a properly endowed chieftain. My discussion below, which emphasizes the narrative and structural complications of the text, should not be understood to preclude the sort of controlling perspective that Viðar proposes.
